statement.text: A pararenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is an aneurysm that involves the aorta at the level of the renal artery origins, where one or both renal arteries arise from the aneurysmal segment itself. Unlike juxtarenal aneurysms (which have a short but uninvolved neck below the renals), pararenal aneurysms require reconstruction or reimplantation of the renal arteries during repair. This anatomic configuration demands either fenestrated/branched endovascular repair or open surgery with visceral vessel reimplantation.
statement.formal: Pararenal AAA: Aneurysm involving the aorta at the level of one or both renal artery origins, requiring renal artery reconstruction or fenestrated endovascular repair for complete exclusion.

explanation.intuition: Imagine a water pipe with a bulge that includes the branch point where two important side pipes connect. You can't simply replace the bulged section without also reconnecting those side pipes. In a pararenal AAA, the kidney arteries come directly off the aneurysm, so any repair must include a plan for maintaining blood flow to the kidneys - either by sewing them onto a new graft or by using special stent-grafts with holes (fenestrations) that allow blood to continue flowing to the kidneys.
explanation.key_insight: The defining characteristic distinguishing pararenal from juxtarenal AAA is whether the renal artery origins are within the aneurysm sac. Juxtarenal has a short neck but the renals come from normal aorta; pararenal has the renal origins embedded in the aneurysm. This distinction fundamentally changes the repair strategy from simple suprarenal clamping to mandatory renal artery reconstruction.
explanation.technical_details: Open repair requires suprarenal or supraceliac clamping with deliberate visceral ischemia. Renal arteries are reimplanted onto the graft, either as a Carrel patch (if origins are close together) or as individual bypass grafts. Cold crystalloid perfusion of the kidneys extends safe ischemia time. Fenestrated EVAR (FEVAR) represents the modern alternative, using custom-manufactured grafts with fenestrations precisely aligned to the renal artery orifices. Bridging stents extend from the fenestrations into the target vessels, maintaining renal perfusion. Chimney/snorkel techniques offer an off-the-shelf alternative with parallel grafts alongside the main endograft body.

presentation: May present with renovascular hypertension if renal artery stenosis coexists
Hematuria if erosion into renal structures (rare)

anatomic_criteria.defining_feature: One or both renal artery origins arise from the aneurysm sac

differentiation.juxtarenal: Short neck (<15mm) but renal origins from normal aorta
differentiation.suprarenal: Aneurysm extends above both renals, involving visceral segment

diagnosis: CT angiography is the gold standard for preoperative planning
Centerline measurements essential for accurate sizing
Assessment of renal function (eGFR, split renal function if asymmetric)

renal_reconstruction: Renal artery bypass grafts (8-10mm Dacron or PTFE)

fenestrated_EVAR.fenestrations: Precisely aligned with renal artery orifices
fenestrated_EVAR.advantages: Avoids open surgery, lower early morbidity
fenestrated_EVAR.disadvantages: Limited to suitable anatomy, requires surveillance, reintervention

chimney_snorkel.indication: Urgent cases where custom FEVAR unavailable
chimney_snorkel.evidence: Less robust long-term data than FEVAR

definition.@value: Abdominal aortic aneurysm involving the aorta at the level of one or both renal artery origins, requiring renal artery reconstruction for complete repair

sources.citation: Society for Vascular Surgery clinical practice guidelines for the management of AAA. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2-77.e2.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition, Chapter 71
European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) 2019 Clinical Practice Guidelines on the Management of Abdominal Aorto-iliac Artery Aneurysms

learning_objectives: Define pararenal AAA by anatomic criteria involving renal artery origins
Distinguish pararenal from juxtarenal and suprarenal aneurysms
Understand renal artery reconstruction techniques in open repair
Compare open repair vs fenestrated EVAR for pararenal anatomy
Describe renal protection strategies during repair
clinical_pearls: Pararenal = renal origins in the aneurysm; juxtarenal = short neck but renals from normal aorta
Carrel patch reimplantation preserves multiple vessel origins in a single patch
Cold renal perfusion extends safe clamp time from 25 to >45 minutes
FEVAR eliminates renal ischemia but requires precise preoperative planning
25-30% of pararenal cases have accessory renal arteries requiring attention

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of visceral aorta with 2 or more visceral artery endoprostheses
